Why Discuss Population Growth?

By Sustainability

tags: sustainability

Discussions of human population growth often make people uncomfortable, so we want to be very clear about our reasons for considering this topic.

  1. Human societies seem to have a number of taboos around the topic of population growth, and we’d like to help us all get past these so we can have open and meaningful discussions on this topic. We’d like to enable discussions that integrate elements of science, critical thinking, cultural evolution and a systemic approach.

  2. In particular, we’d like to help displace fundamentalist religious beliefs stating some sort of injunction to “go forth and multiply” or “be fruitful and increase in number.” Rather than viewing these statements as eternal verities, we’d like to have these viewed in context, appropriate for earlier phases of our cultural evolution, but not terribly meaningful today.

  3. We believe strongly in the power of ordinary individuals to influence our human condition, and we believe that open and meaningful discussions of this topic can help individuals become more conscious of the consequences of their personal choices.

  4. We also believe strongly in improving and broadening human access to education and birth control, to allow all humans to make informed and conscious choices about bringing new children into the world.

  5. We believe that our societies need to be fully aware of both the burdens and benefits of supporting their populations.

  6. We believe strongly in human liberty, equality and democracy, so it is no part of our purpose to encourage or condone any sort of population control that would impose restrictions or sanctions on human reproduction.

  7. Neither is it any part of our intent to advocate for policies that would favor or discourage reproduction by any particular group of humans.
